tweet:
Been bothered for awhile by a patient I helped take care of. They were closer to three times my age than two, and had pretty severe dementia.

They were terrified by everything we were doing to help them, and kept crying for their mom. No amount of soothing or care calmed them.

This is a fine, short read about the end of life and death. My father died suddenly when I was young and away from home. My mother slowly and with dementia and I was present. Even notwithstanding my young age, the suddenness with my dad was a brutal shock. ft.com/content/8dd903‚Ä¶

Late in life she was diagnosed with Alzheimer's and the woman who left this world was but a shadow of the woman who remains in my memories. 

Anyway, no point to this thread other than public reminiscing. 

Happy mother's day, Granny. Thank you. Love you.

My grandmother, who suffers from Lewy body dementia, recognized me first thing at our visit today.

It‚Äôs been well over a year since that kind of clarity of was normal, and I‚Äôm abundantly thankful for it today.

The Lord gives good gifts, even in the midst of suffering and loss.
